comment.narrative: 1. Conduct UN-Wide Social and Economic Impact Analysis 2. Develop Private Sector Recovery Plan 3. Develop Informal Sector Recovery Plan 4. Develop Social Protection Recovery Plan 5. Develop business Continuity Plan for SDP

Under the Socio-Economic Impact and Recovery output, UNDP led the UN-wide Social and Economic Impact Analysis, with ILO, UNICEF, UNFPA, WHO, WB, UNDP, RCO and the UK High Commission. This analysis unpacked the impact of the pandemic across the 5 UN pillars: health first, protecting people, economic recovery, macroeconomic response, and social cohesion and. Based on this, UNDP developed three recovery plans underpinned by the principle of Building Back Better: i) A Private Sector Recovery Plan has been developed for the national private sector network Business Botswana together with ILO and the World Bank. This plan analyses the impact on the private sector and sets out a plan of action in which the private sector takes the lead and initiative to build back better. The plan places a particular focus on digital transformation, green economy, opportunities in the health sector and supporting women and youth-led businesses; ii) ii) An Informal Sector Recovery Plan for the Ministry of Investment Trade and Industry together with ILO and the WB. This plan provided an in-depth analysis of informal sector concepts, definitions, and the multi-faceted impacts of the pandemic. Based on this, clear recommendations and actions were proposed to establish support structures at national and regional levels, whilst also accelerating recovery actions leveraging digital solutions, revitalizing local value chains and marketplaces and building capacities of informal sector participants; and iii) iii) a Social Protection Recovery Plan for the Ministry of Local Government and Rural Development together with UNICEF, ILO, FAO, UNFPA, RCO and WB. This plan evaluated the impact of the pandemic, particularly for the most vulnerable groups. It further reviewed how the current systems responded, and based on this, presented recommendations for how the social protection system could be strengthened. Private Sector & SMEs: Through the Supplier Development Programme, UNDP supported 44 SMEs and 7 large companies with a business continuity planthat facilitated supply chain continuity, access to funding and the diversification of products and markets. All the businesses stayed in business and are now scaling up. Further, UNDP supported 110 entrepreneurs of the national Poverty Eradication programme with PPEs to continue their operations.

comment.narrative: 1.1.1.a:126 village representatives equipped to channel local needs to municipal centers 1.1.1.b: At least 3 municipal shelters properly equipped for needs of elderly and homeless 1.1.1.c: 9,000 (60% of whom women) front-line public-sector workers throughout the country equipped with PPEs 1.1.1.d: At least 10 % increase in the daily response rate of the 144 emergency call center 1.2.1.a: tbd (Number of people reached/engaged throughout the country through COVID-19 public awareness and risk communication activities, broken down by gender and target audiences (general population; the elderly; children/youth/parents; national minorities, persons with disabilities and other marginalized groups). 1.2.1b: At least 300 farm households benefiting from provision of seeds and other agricultural inputs by UNDP, including in Abkhazia, Georgia

1.1.1.a: In progress: to implement the Project output 1.1.1 UNDP has announced a tender to purchase computers for village representatives and signed a PO contract with Multi Solutions Group (MSG) on 26 Oct 2020 at USD 60,984.00 in total. The company took responsibility to provide goods within 60 days. However, on 17 Nov, the company provided an explanation letter referring to the difficulties of suppliers on the global market as a result of the pandemic. Thus, the company said that it will only be able to deliver the goods by mid-February 2021. UNDP conducted an ad hoc market research, which revealed that other companies have the same problems due to the pandemic. Therefore, replacement of the provider was not undertaken, and the project deadline was extended until 31 March. 1.1.1.b: Completed: 3 shelters equipped housing 200 elderly and homeless. 1.1.1.c: Completed: more then 8000 civil servants at central and local levels equipped with PPEs (more then 60 % are women) 1.1.1.d: N/a Relevant data is requested and is awaited from AoG 1.2.1.a: Completed: 120 000 families reached directly through the print materials 1.2.1b: Completed: 480 vulnerable households engaged in small family farming in seven regions have received agricultural inputs. In Abkhazia, 4 agricultural grants were allocated to two women and two men, leading to the creation of 11 new jobs and reaching 60 direct beneficiaries or 15 farmers households.

description.narrative: Livelihood recovery through Covid-19 response activities

comment.narrative:
· As a part of Generation of self- employment and job opportunities through entrepreneurship development, 600 enterprises are targeted to be supported to create jobs for 1000 vulnerable and marginalized population in Sudurpaschim and Karnali Province of Nepal. A rapid Entrepreneurship Development Training has already been conducted for more than 400 individuals ( 40 % women).
· Similarly as a part of Short-term employment support, 250 labor worker, porters including women workers in the tourism section who have lost their jobs are targeted as the beneficiaries for short term employment support in clearing and managing the waste in different trekking routes thereby supporting the workers in the Tourism sector most affected by the pandemic. This activity is being implemented in partnership with the Nepal Tourism Board (NTB). NTB has already coordinated with the respective five municipalities (local governments) in Province no. 1, Province no. 2 and Gandaki Province of Nepal and preparatory work are being done.

comment.narrative: This project is aligned to the global UNDP COVID-19 Response, Policy and Programme Offer, as well as the recently submitted United Nations COVID-19 Response Offer to the Government of Bahrain (April 16th), which proposes 40 service offers from 18 UN entities, ranging from direct support, to monitoring, analysis, capacity development and awareness raising. The UN Response Offer was shared with the Government of Bahrain. UNDP’s main contributions to the Response Offer are in terms of PPE and medical equipment procurement, as well as contributing to a national socio-economic impact assessment. The latter would be conducted with contributions by the UN System, and in particular IOM, UNICEF, ILO, and, UNIDO.

description.narrative: Increased awareness and observance of COVID-19 prevention measures among target populations in the target localities of East Darfur.

comment.narrative: • Training of 100 Community-Based Conflict Resolution Mechanisms members(60 women and 40 men) on COVID19 surveillance, isolating and reporting suspected cases, and outbreak management. • Provide house-to-house COVID19 messaging on prevention, symptoms identification, social distancing to at least 56,700 people, who will be reached by the 100 trained CBRM members in collaboration with other existing trained health workers in the areas. • Establish three (3) Early Warning and Reporting (EWAR) mechanisms, one per the targeted locality, using the trained village development committees, women and youth association group leaders, and conduct active case surveillance in close coordination with SMOH. • Print 30,000 different Information Education and Communication (IEC) materials in Arabic, including pamphlets, based on FMOH/WHO guidelines to be used at health facilities, public areas, and house-to-house distributions, maintaining social distancing. • Install 40 child friendly hand washing facilities at health facilities and other public gathering areas and provision of soap for three months. • Raising communities' awareness using community radio stations for two months, considering the differentiated needs of women, girls, boys, and men in pastoralist, farming, and refugee settings. • Provide assorted Personal Protection Equipment (PPE) to health care service providers in the targeted localities and community outreach workers, if available.

description.narrative: Increased awareness and adherence to COVID-19 Standard Operating Procedures (SoPs) on hygiene and social distancing to avoid infection.

comment.narrative: • Mobilization and sensitization of the communities (at least 20,000 people) in South Darfur on COVID 19. • Establish of steering committee to lead the campaign on COVID19 awareness in the South Darfur communities. • Distribution of prevention kits and materials (to at least 18,000 individuals) in the community. • Publicize the campaign through drama, media and posters at household level and public locations. • Strengthen the culture of cleanliness in the community through six (6) cleaning campaigns in the six (6) targeted clusters targeting market and public spaces

• There was a reported reduction in infection rates in the communities of Alradom and Bilel due to outdoor awareness campaigns led by DPI and its partners. These campaigns carried out using mobile vans during market days sensitized the public about COVID19 prevention measures reaching at least 20,000 community members. • DPI and Partners established 20 steering committees in Bilel and Alradom (10 in each) localities. At least 70% of community members reported to have changed their behaviour due to the efforts of the Steering Committee members leading to improved hygiene in the community. • There was increased hygiene and sanitation after the distribution of COVID19 prevention kits including masks, soap and chlorine which were distributed to 18,000 individuals in the two localities of Alradom and Bilel. These kits made it easy for community members to practise the prevention/hygiene methods that were being taught by the steering committee members. • Drama group presentations as well as distribution of posters increased community awareness on COVID19 prevention leading to increased practise of hygiene and social distancing practises in the Community. This also contributed to the reduced number of cases in the Alradom and Bilel Communities. • Hygiene campaigns conducted in the two localities not only reduced the incidence of COVID19 infection but also reduced the number of people getting diseases caused by poor sanitation such as diarrhoea (reports from the State Ministry of Health indicate a reduction in diarrhoea cases to 40% and other water borne diseases to 34%).

description.narrative: Increase in level of knowledge on COVID-19 prevention behaviours and practices among vulnerable communities in target locations as result of project initiatives.

comment.narrative: • Hold two community mobilization meetings in the communities (in the 10 marketplaces) to share COVID-19 awareness messages • Print and disseminate IPC guidance and messages (36,000 copies of IEC/IPC (posters and fliers) and 10,000 comic books) for home and community care providers in local languages and adopt relevant communication channels. • Enhance risk communication and engagement among groups at risk target villages through providing communities with relevant information on COVID19 using posters, recorded messages and public • Improve access to hand washing facilities and hygiene products through installation of handwashing stations in the 10 targets marketplaces in 14 villages. 100 (20) litre plastic barrels with taps and metal stands will be installed at the 10 central marketplaces • Carry out fumigation of the targeted 10 marketplaces and gathering places. • Support the Ministry of Health (MoH) and government with equipping health facilities with WASH facilities, IPC guidance and IEC materials. Through provision of plastic water storage tank, water and handwashing facilities and soap to six (6) existing health facilities across the 14 villages.

• 16 community mobilization sessions/meetings were held in 10 marketplaces and 6 Health Clinic centres during the project period leading to increased awareness on infection, prevention and control of COVID-19 in the communities. • Printed 20,120 posters and leaflets of different sizes and disseminated the materials to community members at marketplaces and mosques as part of awareness efforts, leading to increased knowledge on COVID-19 prevention measures among these communities. • 8 hakamas were broadcast daily Arabic language for 2 months (14 times per week) on the El Fasher radio stations informing the communities of COVID19 infection, prevention and control. This increased uptake of prevention measures such as washing hands and covering the mouth and nose. • 16 handwashing stations were installed in the 10 targets marketplaces in 14 villages along with 10 plastic 1,000 litre water storage tanks, one for each market. In addition, 88 Cartons of disinfection and sanitization materials and 170 Cartons of hand washing soaps were distributed. These promoted hygiene in the marketplaces as part of the increased access to and utilisation of prevention mechanisms. • 10 plastic water storage tanks of 750 Litres, water and handwashing facilities and soap were also provided to the six (6) health facilities across the 14 villages. This support ensured that community members accessing services at health facilities have access to water for handwashing, soap and information. The project reached about 11,600 persons out of which 50% were women, 40% men and 10% youth and children.

description.narrative: Increased awareness, access and uptake of COVID-19 prevention measures among target populations in the target localities of central Darfur.

comment.narrative: • Establish 5 COVID-19 task force in target localities of Central Darfur (Zalingei, Um Dukhun, Golo, Nertiti, and Rokero). • Support emergency operations states by renting 4 vehicles (two for Zalingei and two for Um Dukhun). • Design and procure signs boards placed at the entrance of Zalingie Isolation centre and teaching hospital. • Procure 8 loudspeakers for State MoH staff from Health promotion department (Loudspeakers) in Zalingie and Um Dukhun for use in community awareness campaigns. In addition, rent sound system for Zalingie Site for 15 days with daily cost of $90 per day and use of microphone in Um-dukhun locality • Produce and distribute COVID-19 guidelines as well as Information Education and Communication (IEC) materials (120 PCs of T. shirt and 120 PCs of Cups) with local messages specifically targeting keys stakeholders and at-risk groups. In addition, print posters, t-shirts and cups with awareness messages to distribute in the communities, hospitals, with at-risk groups and for display in public places. • Hold awareness session on radio in Zalingei and Um Dukhun (2 days per week continues for 5 times with 2,000 SDG per session). • Procure of two plastic water tanks (with 1000L capacity) for the isolation centre. • Provide Zalingie isolation centre with WIFI system to support information sharing. • Engage and conduct sensitization meetings with existing community-based networks, media, local NGOs, schools, local governments and other sectors as education sector, business using a consistent mechanism of communication • Support access to improved hand hygiene, water with soap in public places and community spaces most at risk • Purchase and distribute surgical masks.

• Established five task force groups with a total 20 members, one group in each of the project localities: Zalingei; Um Dukhun; Golo; Nertiti; and Rokero. The task forces were successful in recording, reporting and tracking confirmed cases of COVID-19 in the target localities in Central Darfur hence facilitating coordinated response operations. • Reached the most vulnerable members of the communities through radio sensitization sessions leading increased knowledge of COVID19 whose existence many community members doubted. The sessions also addressed a lot of misinformation that been in communities. • The project team provided training to 100 health facility staff on COVID-19 infection prevention and control (IPC) measures. The training was conducted in both Um Dukhun and Zalingei, leading to increased knowledge on how to manage the medical waste and mitigate COVID-19 spread in health facilities centres. • Ten (10) radio sessions were conducted on Zalingei Radio FM, disseminating information on COVID-19 as well as health messaging on rainy season diseases. These enabled CRS and partners to reach a large part of the community who have limited access to internet and newspapers. Various community members called in during these sessions to get clarification on what COVID 19 is and how they can prevent it. • In order to strengthen information sharing between the locality, the state, and Khartoum, CRS set up a Wi-Fi system with full accessories at the isolation center in Zalingei. This helped facilitate many reports and messages within SMoHSD Central Darfur, and Khartoum, improving both communication speed and operational efficiency. • CRS provided two plastic water tanks for the isolation centers in Zalingei and Um Dukhun, supporting their WASH activities. • CRS provided 16 handwashing stations (eight in each locality) to chools in the Zalingei and Um Dukhun which were conducting Sudanese Certification exams. In Golo, Rokero, Um Dukhun and Zalingei, CRS provided schools with students sitting their exams with 120 bottles of hand sanitizer, 120 bottles of liquid soap, and 10 cartons of tissue paper. The project team also provided SMoH with 12 cartons of facemasks.
